title: compile-fail doctest sometimes erroneously claims code is compilable when it isn't
body:
(example [found](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/ba1d065/src/libsyntax/diagnostic_list.rs#L46-L49) during hour _n_ of chasing down doctest failures for error codes [long forgotten](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/35284))

    $ cat repro.rs 
    #[inline()]
    pub fn something() {}
    
    fn main() {}
    $ rustc repro.rs 
    error[E0534]: expected one argument
     --> repro.rs:1:1
      |
    1 | #[inline()]
      | ^^^^^^^^^^^
    
    error: aborting due to previous error
    
    $ cat repro.md 
    ```compile_fail
    this should fail to compile, because this text is not valid Rust code
    ```
    
    ```compile_fail
    #[inline()]
    pub fn something() {}
    
    fn main() {}
    ```
    $ rustdoc --test repro.md 
    
    running 2 tests
    test repro.md - (line 1) ... ok
    test repro.md - (line 6) ... FAILED
    
    failures:
    
    ---- repro.md - (line 6) stdout ----
        	thread 'rustc' panicked at 'test compiled while it wasn't supposed to', /checkout/src/librustdoc/test.rs:263:12
    note: Run with `RUST_BACKTRACE=1` for a backtrace.
    
    
    failures:
        repro.md - (line 6)
    
    test result: FAILED. 1 passed; 1 failed; 0 ignored; 0 measured; 0 filtered out

The doctest output claims that the code in a `compile_fail` block "compiled while it wasn't supposed to," but we saw just a moment before that that code does not, in fact, compile. 

```
$ rustc --version
rustc 1.21.0-nightly (ed16b0a1d 2017-08-05)
```
